title: Permutation and Its Conditions
description: This lesson introduces permutations as ordered arrangements, explains why order matters, and explores how specific conditions like fixed positions or grouping affect permutations.

lesson.heading: What is a Permutation?
lesson.text: A permutation is an ordered arrangement of objects. Changing the order creates a new arrangement.

lesson.heading: Example 1:
lesson.text: List all the possible three-letter arrangement in the word EAR.

lesson.heading: Solution
bullets: E -> A -> R  ---- E A R
E -> R -> A  ---- E R A
A -> E -> R  ---- A E R
A -> R -> E  ---- A R E
R -> E -> A  ---- R E A
R -> A -> E  ---- R A E

lesson.heading: Example 2:
lesson.text: How many three-letter arrangements in the word EAR can be formed satisfying the given conditions.

bullets: A. the first letter is E
C. the vowels must NOT be together

lesson.heading: Solutions
bullets: A. There are 2 arrangements formed whose first letter is E. Those are EAR and E
B. There are 4 arrangements formed wherein the vowels are together. Those are E
C. There are 2 arrangements formed wherein the vowels are NOT together. Those are ERA and ARE.

lesson.heading: Why Order Matters
lesson.text: In permutations, the order of arrangement is important. ABC and BAC are considered different arrangements.

lesson.heading: Types of Conditions
bullets: Case 1: An element must be in a specific position (e.g., Bobby must be first).
Case 2: Two or more elements must be together (e.g., friends sit side by side).
Case 3: Two or more elements must not be together (e.g., books not next to each other).

lesson.heading: Summary
lesson.text: A permutation is an arrangement where order matters. Conditions can limit or define how objects are arranged.
